image.altText: Sea bird flies past the background landscape of Antarctic island.

props.synopsis: Bird flu is suspected to have reached Australia's sub-Antarctic Heard Island, with signs of the deadly H5 avian disease observed in elephant seals.

title.children: Deadly strain of bird flu suspected on remote Australian island

image.altText: A man wearing a light pink jumper and glasses holds an old book wile sitting in a store surrounded by books.

props.synopsis: There are many factors that can determine the monetary value of a book, so what can make an edition worth tens of thousands of dollars?

title.children: What makes a book valuable? Hint â€” it's not only first editions that are sought after

image.altText: A for lease sign at a picket fence

props.synopsis: Adequate Housing is supposed to be a basic human right ... but around 18,000 Tasmanians don't have a secure home. it's putting downward pressure on an already tight rental market and growing public housing wait list.

title.children: LISTEN to TassieCast ðŸ“¢ Is housing in Tassie a right or a privilege?

image.altText: The back of a young boy's head, looking toward a teacher at the front of a classroom.

props.synopsis: Unions are unhappy with the state government's latest public sector pay offer and are planning stop-work actions next week. Schools and health services for non-urgent patients could be affected.Â

title.children: Schools to shut in Tasmania as unions plan stop-work action over pay offer

image.altText: Rainy weather over Tasmania, as depicted by the BOM radar service.

props.synopsis: Songs about radars strike a chord â€” personally and professionally â€” with Brendan Hanigan. He is tasked with leading the team that keeps Tasmania's weather radars in good working order.

title.children: Radar love not only a 1970s banger, it's life for BOM's Brendan Hanigan

image.altText: An older woman in a green jumper sitting in a park.

props.synopsis: More than 13 years after the Tasmanian state government delivered an apology to mothers impacted by the historical practice of forced adoptions, a redress scheme will offer compensation to those impacted.

title.children: 'Immensely sorry' Tasmanian government offers redress scheme for forced adoptions

image.altText: A graphic with an ambulance in the background, a phone with 000 on it and the logo of Telstra, Optus and Vodafone.

props.synopsis: A Vodafone customer who was repeatedly unable to ring triple-0 says the major telco failed to help her fix the problem for months.

title.children: Vodafone gave mixed messaging over service issues with triple-0, customer says

image.altText: Australian currency

props.synopsis: From phishing to investment cons, scammers are staying "one step ahead" in their efforts to separate us from our savings. Older Australians are often targeted, but there are steps you can take to protect yourself, and those you care about.Â

title.children: Elizabeth clicked on an email link and lost her life savings

image.altText: Anthony Albanese in a beige and brown patterned shirt stands at a lectern, with four Pacific leaders behind him.

props.synopsis: Beijing reprimanded Pacific Island nation ambassadors for including Taiwan in the regional summit last month, but Australia and New Zealand have lent their support.

title.children: Australia backs Pacific Islands facing China heat over Taiwan

image.altText: A man being led by police.

props.synopsis: Police allege three men falsely claimed to be mediating between a construction company and unions to prevent disruptions at buildings sites.

title.children: Three men charged with alleged $6.6 million construction extortion

image.altText: A low angle shot of a black bike seat with a woman standing behind, back to the camera.

props.synopsis: "Saddle soreness" is a common complaint among cyclists. These innovators are looking at creative ways to prevent it by redesigning the bike seat.

title.children: Could a new bike seat prevent saddle pain? These innovators think so

image.altText: Minister for Environment Murray Watt speaking.

props.synopsis: Environment Minister Murray WattÂ links the passage of Labor's Environmental Protection Reform Bill to critical minerals, housing and renewable energy projects.

title.children: Minister says critical minerals, housing will suffer if environment laws aren't passed

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Greens open to negotiating with Labor on environmental protection reforms

image.altText: A hand holds a mobile phone with the screen showing several social media apps

props.synopsis: Police did not know his name but they did have his Snapchat handle. From there, detectives pieced together a case that would reveal the true identity of sex offender 'Alec'.

title.children: The digital breadcrumb that led police to 'Alec', a child sex offender

image.altText: An X-ray showing metallic items in a boy's abdominal area.

props.synopsis: Surgeons in New Zealand had to remove part of the 13-year-old boy's bowel after he obtained banned magnets online.

title.children: Teenager has surgery after swallowing 100 magnets

image.altText: A submarine at the surface with morning sun on its right flank, the ocean stretches behind it

props.synopsis: In Washington on Monday, Anthony Albanese made something clear once again: Australia is all-in on the trilateral defence pact. Clarifying what US powerbrokers think remains a multi-billion-dollar question.

title.children: Australia is all in on AUKUS. In Donald Trump's America, it's more complicated

image.altText: Two men are holding a fabric with a camouflage military pattern inside a factory.

props.synopsis: As US President Donald Trump visits South-East Asia amid global trade tensions, Indonesian exporters worry the region could bear the brunt of his protectionist policies.

title.children: Trump's tariffs would change this city once known as Indonesiaâ€™s textile hub

image.altText: A black object on a dusty red dirt road.

props.synopsis: How closely were you following the news this week? Test yourself to find out!

title.children: News quiz: A jewel heist, an awkward Trump moment and an outback mystery

image.altText: .A young woman with fair skin and brown hair

props.synopsis:
Despite one in four sufferers being under 65, experts say there is a common misconception that strokes only occur in older people. Mental well-being is key to recovery but is often more difficult for younger stroke survivors.
Â

title.children: Elena was a fit and healthy 20-year-old â€” then she had a stroke

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is around the flatline on Friday following gains on Wall Street, but may still manage a weekly gain. Investor sentiment has been buoyed by news that Donald Trump plans to meet with Xi Jinping, while US sanctions on Russia have pushed oil prices higher. Follow live.

title.children: ASX on track for weekly gain as critical minerals, energy stocks rise

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Consumer watchdog vows to support Australians' access to cash
Transporting cash remains an issue: RBA Governor

image.altText: The sun in a cloudy sky sets over a beach

props.synopsis: Temperatures are set to reach above 40 degrees in some places, with more hospital admissions likely because of heat-related illness.Â

title.children: 'Huge bubble of hot air' across northern Australia as heatwave persists

image.altText: A Wallabies rugby union player looks back as he sprints away holding the ball to score a try.

props.synopsis: Wallabies coach-in-waiting Les Kiss is an admirer of Kangaroos debutant Mark Nawaqanitawase, who he says will return to union in 2027 wiser and a better player.

title.children: Kangaroo Nawaqanitawase will earn Wallabies recall in 2027, says Les Kiss

image.altText: A man with shoulder-length brown hair and beard looks neutrally at the camera

props.synopsis: Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, is charged with "maliciously" starting a fire in January that killed 12 people. If he is convicted he could spend up to 45 years in jail.

title.children: LA's Pacific Palisades fire suspect pleads not guilty

image.altText: A pair of women in Team Australia uniforms row a boat.

props.synopsis: The world's top rowing and canoeing bodies say they are conducting their own assessments of the Fitzroy River ahead of the 2032 Games despite Queensland politicians insisting events will be held there.

title.children: Rowing body pours cold water on 'green light' claim for Olympic events

image.altText: GettyImages-2178235912

props.synopsis: Kenya's Ruth Chepngetich is banned from athletics for three years over a doping violation.

title.children: Marathon world record-holder banned for three years over doping violation

image.altText: Woman in black dress walking on path in botanic garden leading a group of five women, among green shrubbery and trees.

props.synopsis: A growing number of women are entering the in-demand cultural tourism field in which First Nations guides share treasured knowledge.

title.children: Indigenous women lead increasingly popular cultural tourism trend

image.altText: Girls in traditional dress smiling on a stage

props.synopsis: A native title claim in the region where Captain James Cook made landfall after his ship crashed into the Great Barrier Reef in 1770 is among one of three to finally be settled by the Federal Court this week.

title.children: Cape York land returned to owners 255 years after Captain James Cook arrived

image.altText: Three people playing cricket on the dish

props.synopsis:
The film The Dish helped reintroduce a new generation of Australians to the critical role the Parkes Observatory played in the Moon landing. Twenty-five years after its release, the film has had a lasting impact.

Â

title.children: How the Dish catapulted a rural observatory to international fame

image.altText: A female cricketer holds her bat and helmet aloft in triumph.

props.synopsis: Smriti Mandhana scores her third century of the World Cup as a monster partnership with fellow opener Pratika Rawal delivers India a crucial win against New Zealand.

title.children: Indian openers register 37-year first to qualify for World Cup semifinal

image.altText: Black and white image of toddler with fair hair in front of tree

props.synopsis: NSW MP Jeremy Buckingham used parliamentary privilege to read a 1971 confession in the Cheryl Grimmer case, bypassing decades of legal silence. Outside parliament, the man's identity remains legally suppressed.

title.children: Why the identity of a cold case murder confessor remains under wraps

image.altText: A young female Paralympian holding flower while celebrating winning a silver medal

props.synopsis: Sydney 2000 was a turning point â€” not just for me, but for the entire Paralympic movement, writes silver medallist Elizabeth Wright.

title.children: Winning a silver medal at the Sydney Paralympics changed everything

image.altText: A dolphin in the ocean with a brown sea sponge on it.

props.synopsis: Scientists observe male humpback dolphins parading sea sponges on their heads to impress females off Western Australia's northern coast.

title.children: Male dolphins spotted donning sea-sponge wigs to attract females

image.altText: The front facade of an art deco style cinema

props.synopsis: After sitting idle for two decades residents of the NSW town of Mudgee have purchased the iconic Regent Theatre, with plans to return it to its former glory.

title.children: 'Upset' locals decide to buy mothballed theatre
